newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-FORECAST-Copper seen key in MIM loss.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-FORECAST-Copper seen key in MIM loss.

text.p: The slump in the copper price last year and a strong Australian dollar are expected to have driven base metals miner MIM Ltd into the red in the first half of the year, analysts said on Thursday.
MIM is expected to report a net loss before abnormals and exchange losses of A$10 million to A$20 million early on Friday, due largely to a hefty loss from the Mt Isa copper operations.
This compares with a profit of A$23.6 million before abnormals and exchange effects in the first half of 1995/96.
"The key number we'll be looking for is the EBIT number for Mt Isa copper," said one Sydney analyst, adding a loss of A$50 million to A$100 million was possible on Mt Isa operations.

"It really comes down to how much cost cutting has been achieved at Mt Isa and the extent of the exchange losses," he said. He saw a loss for MIM of A$10 million to A$15 million before abnormals and exchange losses.
MIM's ability to extract efficiency gains at its Mt Isa operations were seen as another key factor to watch.

ANZ Securities research manager Chris Bain said he was expecting a loss of up to A$20 million and that the market was expecting a poor result. "The key will be progress on Alumbrera and Ernest Henry and any updates on the industrial relations climate at Mt Isa," Bain said.
A weak copper price was likely to have depressed Mt Isa profits, analysts said.
"Basically all operations beside McArthur River probably made money at the operational level," a Melbourne analyst said.
"It's just that copper has made a lot less and when you put corporate, exploration and other costs on it has made a loss in the end," the analyst said.
Resources director at Brisbane broker Wilson HTM, Phillip Hutchings, said he expected a loss of around A$20 million.
"It's a combination of a lower copper price, a lower zinc price and a high exchange rate," he said.
"They have had problems in their coal operations as well."
MIM shares closed down three cents at A$1.74 on Thursday.
